coredata.dc:title: Photophysical studies of pyrene on oxide supports. The effect of surface modification on probe dispersion and mobility
coredata.dc:creator: Francis, Colin
Lin, John
Singer, Lawrence A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The pyrene monomer—excimer system was studied, under oxygen-free conditions, on silica and silylated silica in the loading range 2–200 μmole pyrene/g oxide. An analysis of the non-exponential monomer fluorescence decays in terms of a statistical model for probe adsorption and diffusive excimer formation is reported.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 94. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS - 141anuary 1983 PHOTOPHYSICAL STUDIES OF PYRENE ON OXIDE SUPPORTS. THE EFFECT OF SURFACE MODIFICATION ON PROBE DISPERSION AND MOBILITY Colin FRANCIS. John LIN and Lawrence A. SINGER Dehartinent of Clfeutistry. Unirersitt. of Southern Califonda, Los Attgeles. Califontia 90089-1062, USA Received 1 3 September 1982:?n final form 18 October 1982 The pyre ne monomer-excinier system was studied. under oxyen-free conditions. on silica and silylated silica in the loading range 2-=t10 uinole pyrenc g oxide. An analysis of the non-exponential monomer fluorescence decays in terms of a statistical model for probe adsorption and diffusive excinier formation is reported. 1.Introduction lit the field of lietero;eneous catalysis, the most important indicator of the effectiveness of a catalyst is provided by its activity-and the selectivity it imposes on a particular chemical reaction. However, a detailed knowledge of the microscopic properties of the catalyst system (for example. the nature of the adsorption sites. the structure of surface species, and their mobility/reactivity on the catalyst surface) is essential to the understanding of these macroscopic observations. Although a wide range of spectroscopic techniques (1 4) have been used with some degree of success to obtain stlrh detailed information (for example IR. Ranian. l1V -VIS, LSR. NN-111, XPS and EXAFS), an additional inetllodulogy that has been essentially overlooked to date. although appearing to be particularly suited for such studies. is fluorescence spectroscopy. Tu this end. we have initiated a photophysical study of pyfene till silica and silylated silica in which the pyrene mononleriexclnler system [S ] is exploited as a dispersion and mobility probe- During the course of this snide. we became aware of other recent work ohich complements our own [6j. 2. Experimental Dispersions of pyrene on silica (Davison Chemical, 162 Sylox 24, 150 in 2/g) were prepared as follows. A mixture of 0.5 g of silica or silylated silica * in 10 ml of 0.01-0.05 M pyrene in hexane was stirred for several hours, centrifuged, and the recovered solid washed with fresh hexane, and dried under vacuum. This procedure optimizes the dispersion of pyrene over the surface of the oxide and thus minimizes multilayer formation. The adsorbed pyrene was directly assayed by ultraviolet-visible absorption spectroscopy on silica samples suspended in a liquid siloxane (such as octatttetltylcyclotetrasiloxane) closely matched in refractive index with the solid. We found that by varying several parameters (concentration of pyrene in hexane, stirring time, extent of washing), we could prepare loadings that correspond to 2 to nearly 200 gmole/g support. Pyrex cuvettes containing samples of the coated oxides were degassed and sealed. Such samples appear to be stable for at least several weeks even when The silica surface was modified by adding 50 ml of dry toluene, followed by 10 inl of trimethylsilyl chloride. to 1.0 - of silica ldried at 250 C under vacuum (10-2 Torr) for 48 h 1. The slurry was stirred for 24 li at room temperature under a dynamic nitrogen atmosphere to remove any HCI generated in the silylation procedure. The toluene and excess triniethylsilyl chloride were removed under vacuum. the oxide washed once with hexane and then allowed to stand under dynamic vacuum for a few hours. The presence of trimethylsilyl groups on the surface was confirmed by transmission IR spectroscopy. 0 009-2614/83/0000-0000/S 03.00 1983 North-Holland Volume 94; number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 14 January 1983 exposed to visible light- In contrast, pyrene coated on silica under atmospheric conditions rapidly deteriorates in the presence of ordinary room light. Other work in progress indicates that this high reactivity results from facile pyrene-sensitized singlet oxygen generation under these heterogeneous conditions [7]. The fluorescence decays and spectra from the degassed pyrene on oxide samples were obtained by nitrogen laser excitation (337 rim, 10 ns pulse) in conjunction with a PAR 160 boxcar integrator for timegated monitoring [8]. 3: Results 31. Emission spectra Fig. 1 shows the total emission from pyrene (monomer and excimer) adsorbed on silica and modified silica, respectively. The monomer fluorescence (highly structured band near 390 nm) decreases and the corresponding excimer fluorescence (structureless band near 450 nm) increases with increasing coverage of the oxide surface in both series. However, it is clear that the excimer/monomer fluorescence ratio increases much more rapidly on the unmodified surface- These trends seem to imply higher dispersion of the probe on the silylated surface. The monomer and excimer emissions in fig. i are similar in detail to those generally observed in solution [5] indicating little perturbation of these systems by the oxide support (a weak support effect). Further information may be derived from an analysis of the vibrational fine structure of the monomer fluorescence. Kalyanasundaram and Thomas [9] have shown that the relative intensities of the three highest energy vibrational bands are particularly sensitive to the polarity of the tllicroenvirontllent_ Vibrational band intensities (1, 11 and 111) from 6g. I are compared with those from relevant media in table i _ The data in table I indicate that the pyrene probe on the modified surface experiences a microenvironment similar to solution in tetramethylsilane or poly(dimethylsfoxane), consistent with derivatization of the surface with trimethylsilyl groups. On the other hand, the monomer fluorescence band intensities for the unmodified silica case do not agree well with those for pyrene either in aqueous or a poly- I II III r f 1 ., ~ r _' 1~ ,k /'(A C D :roo soo ! i?ii ~~II'~ ---TIII ~. i ~a 400 500 nm Fig. 1. This reaction scheme is analogous to the one deriv- ed by us and others [12] for intrarnicellar pyrene excimer formation- By analogy with the intramicellar case, the above scheme leads to the following expression for the time dependence of the monomer fluorescence: In(I(10)=it[exp(-ket)- 1 ] -kit where IO and I are the emitted light intensities at t = 0 and t, respectively, and il is the average number of neighboring pyrene molecules. At large t, the function assumes the exponential form (4) ln(1/lo).' -(ii+klt) sa that the limiting slope provides a measure of kl and the extrapolated intercept provides il. Figs. 2 and 3 show the monomer fluorescence decay behavior for a series of pyrene Ioadings on silica and the silylated silica. The strategy for determining the best-fit values for the parameters kl , ke, and n is as follows. Note. limiting: slope for D corresponds to a lifetime of 250 ns. of k 1 for pyrene on silica (kl = 5-I X 106 s-1) and silylated silica (k l =4.8 X 106 s'-I), and the extrapolated intercepts provide estimates of n (iz = 0.43 at 1 98 llmolelg silica; iz = 0.45 at 4.84 umole/g silylated silica). The decays are then simulated over all t using eq. (4) by adjusting the magnitude of k.- Tlle best-fit simulations for these lowest loading cases in figs. 2a and 3a provide ke = 2.5 X 107 s-I on silica and kc = 2.0 X 107 5-I on the silylated surface. The monomer fluorescence decays for the higher coverages are then simulated by fixing the magnitudes of kl and ke with the derived values and varying the magnitude of zi. This procedure proved adequate for all cases except the highest loading on the silylated surface (136 ymole pyrene/g support) where a good fit of the data could only be obtained using a somewhat longer lifetime (250 instead of 210 ns) for the monomer fluorescence lifetime. The results are given in table 2 with the best-fit simulations plotted in figs. 2 and 3. If all excimer sites were to arise via the diffusive encounter mechanism, the excinter fluorescence should show a measurable risetinle (izke). Although non-exponential decay behavior is observed (fig. 4), no such risetime is noted. Instead, the decay is more consistent with a finite contribution from static dinler sites in addition to diffusivelv formed excirners. X is the relative number of static dirner sites. a is the relative number of diffusively formed dieter sites. k 'I is the excimer decay rate, and A = irke/(k i - irke). The excinier decays for the lowest loadings of pyrette on silica and silylated silica were simulated by eq. (6) using the magnitudes of irk, provided by the ntonorner decay simulation, and then varying k i , X and X'. The values of the parameters for the besttit simulations shown in Ca. 4 are liven in table 3. The above simulations indicate that almost half of the excinters arise from static dieter sites for these lowest loadin-, cases. Further. the relative number of initial monomer to dintar sites may be estimated as follonvs. Analysis of the total emission spectra in fig. 1 indicates that (area of morionier fluorescence)/ (area of excinier fluorescence) = 1.61 and 1.30 for tits lowest loadings on silica and silylated silica. respectively. If we assume that the intrinsic radiative rate cunstatlts for the monomer (1.5 X 106 s-I) and excinier ( 1._' X 107 s-i ) in liquid phase [;) are applicable. the fluorescence quantum yields of tl>%l = 0.2'11 and (I)1._ = 0_30 fur pyrene on silica are derived front the ntononler and excinier fluorescence lifetimes-of 1 116 and ?3 its. Similarly, cl>>l = 0.37 arid rlrE = 0__'t) are obtained for pyrene on the silylated surface using the fluorescence lifetimes of 310 and ?4ris_ The fluorescence area ratios and applicable mortonler/excitner quantum yield ratios provide (inononter sites)/(excinter sites) = 1.67 and 1.18 for tile lowest loadings on silica and silylated silica, respectively. Finally. from these values and the ratio of 166 the number of static dimers to diffusively formed dimers (from the excimer transient data), the ratios of (intrinsic monomer sites)/(intrinsic dimer sites) are estimated to be 5.1/1.0 (1770 dieter sites) for pyrene on silica and 4.0/1.0 (20%o dimer sites) for pyrene on silylated silica. Thus, at more than twice the loading of pyrene on the silylated surface, only a sli,lttly greater number of dimer sites are present relative to the unmodified oxide. 4. Summary In table 4, a number of the key results from this study are summarized. First, although the monomer and excimer fluorescence spectra are similar to those in solution, we note that the limiting monomer and excinier lifetimes, deduced via our kinetic model, are shorter than those generally observed in liquid phase Table 4 Summary of important paratneters pltotopltysical parameters rf fns) rI- (n5) mobility parameters ke(s 1) distribution parameters ntonotner initial sites (%) 8 3 dinter initial sites (!yr.) 17 dinner sites (statieldiffusive) a) 1.98 umolc%~! support. :'yrene on oxide system silica a) silylatcd silica b) 196 210 25 24 3.5 X 107 2_0 X 10' 80 20 100J125 100/130 b) 4.8411 mole%g support. Volume 94, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 14 January 1983 under deoxygenated conditions (see also ref. [6J). The results also indicate comparable encounter rates on the two surfaces, although the distribution data suggest higher dispersion of probe molecules on the surface of the silylated oxide. In the absence of detailed information concerning the real surface area available to the adsorbed pyrene, we can obtain the rate of encounter between probe molecules, but not the encounter distance. The similar encounter rates but different dispersions may arise as a result of different surface environments (meaning a change in support-probe interaction), or simply reflect an increase in surface area on the silylated oxide due to the modification procedure: This point is the focus of current studies. Finally, we believe that this study demonstrates that fluorescence probe methodologies may be used to investigate the mobility and distribution of adsorbed molecules. It is important to stress, however, that although our kinetic model provides a rationale for the observed experimental data, it may not preclude other explanations. For example, the present results do not exclude an energy, migration mechanism based on Forster energy transfer between monomers as well as between monomers and dimers (which could act as energy traps)- Further, some combination of energy and molecular migration is also possible wherein an excited monomer diffuses to within Forster transfer distance of a dimer site before the energy transfer occurs. Studies now in progress may help elucidate among these mechanistic possibilities. Acknowledgement CF wlslies to thank the Research Corporation for a grant in partial support of this work. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The pyrene monomer—excimer system was studied, under oxygen-free conditions, on silica and silylated silica in the loading range 2–200 μmole pyrene/g oxide. An analysis of the non-exponential monomer fluorescence decays in terms of a statistical model for probe adsorption and diffusive excimer formation is reported.
